metadata.sermon_start_end: Many of my clergy friends and I look forward to the time, every three years, when St. Paul’s Epistle to the Romans is read all through the summer. It affords an unparalleled opportunity to preach straight through this great letter. I am always thrilled when the third year comes [...] He who did not spare his own Son but gave him up for us all, will he not also give us all things with him? Who shall bring any charge against God’s elect? It is God who justifies; who is to condemn?… Christ Jesus, who died, yes, who was raised from the dead, who is at the right hand of God, indeed intercedes for us. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Romans 8:33-34 as a springboard, but quickly drifts into general themes of forgiveness and reconciliation. It fails to identify what is unique to this specific verse that cannot be found elsewhere. The focus on 'justification' as 'rectification' is a theological choice, but the sermon spends more time on external anecdotes (South Africa, Lockerbie) than on the specific logic of Paul's forensic rhetoric in these two verses.
quotes: One of Paul’s most important themes could be stated as 'There but for the grace of God go I.'
It is a huge challenge to interpret this word... Here it is in our passage from Romans for today: 'It is God who justifies; who is to condemn?'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific 'proclamatory word' of verse 33. Why does Paul use the legal metaphor of 'charging' and 'condemning' here specifically? Avoid reducing the text to a general 'theme' of the letter.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is almost no technical exegesis. The preacher mentions the difficulty of the word 'justify' but does not engage with the Greek 'dikaioō' or the specific covenantal/forensic context of Paul’s argument. The historical context of the Roman congregation is absent. The preacher relies on modern theological categories (Bonhoeffer) rather than original context.
quotes: Preachers and Bible teachers have been struggling for years to find the best way of making this word live.
That is what justification means: God is going to justify, God is going to rectify...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the 'Hebrew and Greek' requirement by explaining the forensic nature of justification in its 1st-century context to ground the 'rectification' claim.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest part of the sermon. The use of the Lockerbie bombing, the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission, and Father Jenco provides concrete, non-general examples of the 'zeitgeist'. It avoids 'cheap' general truths by looking at the agony of injustice.
quotes: Susan Cohen, a woman who lost her only child, Theodora, age 20, seven years ago on Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie.
Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu is head of a special commission that is conducting hearings about atrocities...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows directly from the text's specificity rather than using the text as a label for pre-selected social examples.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured as a series of reflections on forgiveness followed by a brief look at the word 'justification'. The 'exposition' (what the text meant) and 'application' (what it means now) are somewhat siloed. The hearer is not so much 'drawn into the text' as they are given a lecture on a concept illustrated by the text.
quotes: And so Paul does not use the word 'forgiveness.' He uses another word.
Imagine something that we have all seen from time to time... a group of hobo craftsmen...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Mix the exegesis of the word 'justify' directly into the narrative of the Lockerbie mother's grief to show how the text 'expounds' her situation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (sin, injustice, the 'pariah') and Redemption (Christ's death, no condemnation) are present. Gratitude is less explicit but implied in the 'pilgrimage to reconciliation'. The sermon correctly identifies misery as 'misery before God' and redemption as 'outside man'.
quotes: There is liberation in the Christian confession of sin and unworthiness before God.
Christ’s death on the Cross—the ultimate price—has removed the everlasting condemnation from us.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Make the 'gratitude' (the third part) more visible as the necessary response to the 'rectification' described, avoiding a purely objective description of God's work.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon leans heavily towards a universalist tone ('Nothing can separate us from the love of God, not even our own worst selves'). While it mentions the 'Last Judgment', it softens the 'two ways' by suggesting that even sin cannot separate us, potentially undermining the 'seriousness of life design' Dekker demands.
quotes: Sin cannot separate us from Christ. If it can, we are indeed doomed.
God isn’t just going to pat humanity on the head... that is called denial.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'temporal loss' or the 'narrow way' more sharply. If 'nothing separates us', the preacher must explain why human choice and the 'two ways' still matter for the 'willing and responsible being'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, specifically through the cross and intercession. The sermon affirms the costliness of grace and the necessity of Christ's death. However, the connection between Christ's 'two natures' and the 'rectification' of the Lockerbie tragedy remains slightly abstract.
quotes: God 'did not spare his own Son but gave him up for us all.'
Christ Jesus... who is at the right hand of God, indeed intercedes for us.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'intercession' of Christ (v. 34) to the specific 'rectification' of the victims' agony to make Christ more than just a theological necessity.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,450 words, the sermon would take roughly 14-15 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth'. It falls short of the 20-minute minimum.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary theological 'breadth' that would bring the sermon over the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its brevity and its lack of rigorous, language-based exegesis. While it excels in concrete contemporary application (South Africa, Lockerbie), it treats the biblical text more as a thematic anchor than a specific, unique revelation. The 'two ways' are obscured by a strong emphasis on the impossibility of separation from God, which risks losing the 'seriousness of the journey' Dekker emphasizes.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of specific, high-stakes human events (apartheid, terrorism) avoids the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
Theological sobriety: The distinction between 'free' and 'cheap' grace is handled with appropriate weight.
weaknesses: Insufficient length: At ~14 minutes, it lacks the 'breadth' required for homiletic depth.
Lack of specific exegesis: The preacher does not engage with the original languages or the unique 'nowhere else' quality of the pericope.
Weak 'Two Ways': The sermon risks a soft universalism that may not take the 'ultimate possibilities of life design' seriously enough.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an 'adequate' speech with strong illustrative power, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the full Dekkerian sense due to its lack of exegetical depth and insufficient duration.
